turns.speaker: J
turns.text: Hello, can I help you?

turns.speaker: PLANK
turns.text: All right, it's Plank. Is Willie there?

turns.speaker: J
turns.text: No, I'm afraid he's not. He's out at the moment.

turns.speaker: PLANK
turns.text: Well, perhaps you can help?

turns.speaker: J
turns.text: Well, perhaps I can't, Plank, if you know what I mean.

turns.speaker: PLANK
turns.text: Look, could you just open the door so I could talk without shouting?

turns.speaker: J
turns.text: I can't help you, Plank.

turns.speaker: PLANK
turns.text: I think you'll find it is in your interest.

turns.speaker: J
turns.text: Hold on. OK.  Look Willie, it's Plank outside asking for you, he says it's in our interest.

turns.speaker: PLANK
turns.text: I thought you were going to leave me out there all day.

turns.speaker: J
turns.text: I didn't know you were a kebab man, Plank.

turns.speaker: PLANK
turns.text: Lives and learns doesn't one.

turns.speaker: J
turns.text: Sorry, got to do business like this now; can't be too careful these days.

turns.speaker: PLANK
turns.text: I know.  Now shut it. You say a fucking word the right knee goes, another word then your left.

turns.speaker: J
turns.text: What are you doing, Plank?

turns.speaker: PLANK
turns.text: What do you think I am doing? Hold on. What are you doing? Unlock that gate. Oi! I said unlock that fucking gate.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: What are you talking about? I am bloody skinny, pal.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Of course you are. All right, Ed.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: How much did you say it was, Tom?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: You know how much it is, Nick.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: And that does include the amp?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: You know it doesn't include the amp.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Not normal weed. This is some fucked-up skunk class A. I can't think let alone move shit.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Doesn't sound very good to me.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Neither me, but it depends on what flicks your switch, and the light's on and burning bright for the masses.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Jews don't celebrate Christmas, Tom.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Never mind that now. I also need some artillery, you know, a couple of sawn-off shotguns.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Bloody hell, Tom! This is a bit heavy. This is London, not the Lebanon' Who do you think I am?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I think you're Nick the Greek.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Jesus, if I pick them up, will they stay in one piece? Where did you get them from?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I got contacts. Listen Tom, if you pointed them at me I'd shit myself or do whatever you said to do. Either way you still get the desired effect.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: They look nice, I agree . . . but lacking in criminal credibility, aren't they? I might get laughed at. How much do you want for these muskets?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Seven hundred each.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Sawn-offs are out, Tom; people like to have a bit mare range nowadays.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Range? I don't want to blow the arse out of this country, granted, but I don't want anybody blowing a raspberry at me either. I want to look fucking mean.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Of course you will look mean, Tom, you will look really scary.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: All right, let's forget about them for the time being. What about your weed man?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Rory Breaker is standing by. You stand to make a lot of money, Tommy boy.

turns.speaker: TRAFFIC WARDEN
turns.text: You got a ticket already and, if you don't move it now, sir, we will move it for you.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I'll only be a minute.

turns.speaker: TRAFFIC WARDEN
turns.text: You've already been fifteen.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Look. Go on, look.

turns.speaker: TRAFFIC WARDEN
turns.text: At what, exactly?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: My van is half full.

turns.speaker: TRAFFIC WARDEN
turns.text: So?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: So I've just got to put you in, and I am off.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: What have you come as?

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: Cupid stupid! That's the last time I am getting any more fruit off you Tom. Call that fresh? There was more small hairy armoured things in your fruit than there was fruit. You should open a butcher's, not a grocer's.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: If you will order stuff that comes from Kat-Man-Fucking-Du don't be surprised if your fruit picks up a few tourists en route. ~ Never mind that, what about the money?

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: Get your fingers out of my soup!

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: So, a reasonable return should be in the region of one hundred and twenty, for twenty-five grand invested. That's going on previous experiences.

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: That's going on optimism.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Whatever it's going on, it's still enough to send you on a cooking course.

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: You're not funny Tom; you're fat and look as though you should be funny, but you're not.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: What you telling us for? The only thing I care about is whether you get your rest in.

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: Tom, you're all heart.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Listen cooky, you want to make sure that man rests before he plays; it's in all our interests.

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: Oh, you assume, do ya? What do they say about assumption being the brother of all fuck-ups?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: It's the mother of fuck-ups, stupid!

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: Well, excuse me, brother, mother or any other sucker, doesn't make any difference, they are still fucking guns, and they still fire fucking bullets!

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: Where did you get those from, a museum?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Nick the Greek.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Well Jesus, that wasn't so bad, was it?

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: When the bottle in my arse has contracted I'll let you know.

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: What's left over?'

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Hold on, give us half a chance to count it.

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: What about all the gear?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: This guy Rory Breaker can afford to do the deal at the price we are selling. It's not worth him giving us trouble; he knows we would be a pain in the arse, and who wants a pain in the arse?

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: I would take a pain in the arse for half a million.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: You would take a pain Ã­n the arse full stop.

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: Tom, the fatter you get, the sadder you get.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: There's six black cocks sitting on the side of the road. How many beaks have they got between them?

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: Six.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: How many wings have they got between them?

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: Twelve.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: How many feet?

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: Er, well, twelve.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: That's right. So how many whiskers has the little white kitten got?

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: How the fuck should I know?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: How come you know so much about black cocks and so little about white pussy?]

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: The money, the gear!

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: That's fucked it. What do we do now? No money, no weed; it's all been swapped for a pile of corpses.

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: OK, don't panic; let's think about this.

turns.speaker: WILLY
turns.text: Chill, Winston, it's me and Charlie can see it's me, so what's the problem?

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: The problem is, Willy, that Charlie and yourself are not the quickest of cats in the alley at the best of times, so just do as I say and keep the fucking cage locked.

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: What are you carrying, Willy?

turns.speaker: WILLY
turns.text: Er, fertilizer.

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: You went out six hours ago to buy a money counter and you come back carrying two bags of fertilizer. Alarm bells are ringing, Willy.

turns.speaker: WILLY
turns.text: We need fertilizer, Winston.

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: We also need a fucking money counter, William! We have to get the money out by Thursday and I'll be buggered if I am counting it . . . and if you have to get your sodding fertilizer, couldn't you be a little more subtle?

turns.speaker: WILLY
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: I mean we grow copious amounts of ganja, and you don't look like your average hort-er-fucking-culturalist, that's what I mean, Willy.

turns.speaker: PALOMA
turns.text: You jerk--

turns.speaker: AMADO
turns.text: I'm not talking to you. You don't have any friends.

turns.speaker: PALOMA
turns.text: Who'd want to be friends with that bunch of pachuco wannabes?

turns.speaker: AMADO
turns.text: I don't pretend I came over on the Mayflower--

turns.speaker: PALOMA
turns.text: And those stupid girls who hang out with them--

turns.speaker: AMADO
turns.text: Just shut up.

turns.speaker: PALOMA
turns.text: Joanie Orozco's telling the whole school she's like desperately in love with Santo Guerra.

turns.speaker: AMADO
turns.text: So?

turns.speaker: PALOMA
turns.text: It's pathetic. You can't be desperately in love when you're 14 years old.

turns.speaker: AMADO
turns.text: I don't know what the big deal is.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: You'll find out when I get you home. Thanks, Sam.

turns.speaker: AMADO
turns.text: If you had your way I wouldn't have any friends.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Oh, come on, Amado--

turns.speaker: AMADO
turns.text: Just 'cause I'm not like Little Miss Honor Roll here--

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Leave your sister out of it.

turns.speaker: AMADO
turns.text: You and all of the teachers in this dump--your story's over, so you don't want anybody else to have fun.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: I'm only going to have you for two more years. If you decide not to go on to college--

turns.speaker: AMADO
turns.text: I can't take any more school.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: --you're going to be on your own.

turns.speaker: AMADO
turns.text: So?

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: So I'm worried about you. I don't want you to end up in jail like your friends.

turns.speaker: AMADO
turns.text: They're not going to jail.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Don't try to con me, Amado. You knew how they got all those things.

turns.speaker: AMADO
turns.text: Just some rich Anglo out on the lake. Don't even live here all year.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: That makes it okay?

turns.speaker: AMADO
turns.text: They stole our land--

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Save your breath. That line doesn't cut it with me.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: How do you think you're going to make a living?

turns.speaker: AMADO
turns.text: I can fix cars.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: You can fix old cars. Mr. Washburn told me that the cars they're making now are all computerized--

turns.speaker: AMADO
turns.text: You think I can't learn that?

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: I think you can learn whatever you want to. I just don't see you doing it. If you want to settle for--

turns.speaker: AMADO
turns.text: I'm not settling for anything. I like cars, it's just not a move up the ladder to you, so you think it's a waste.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: That isn't true.

turns.speaker: AMADO
turns.text: Oh, come on--you and Grandma think anybody who works with their hands is a peasant. When Dad--

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: If you grew up to he anywhere near as good a man as your father was, I would be happy! I would be thrilled.

turns.speaker: AMADO
turns.text: It's my life. If I want to fuck it up, that's my business.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: I said pretty much the same thing to my mother when I was your age.

turns.speaker: AMADO
turns.text: And what did she do?

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Two years at hard labor, Our Lady of Perpetual Help.

turns.speaker: AMADO
turns.text: Catholic school, nasty.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: Private Johnson, are you unhappy in the Army?

turns.speaker: ATHENA
turns.text: No, sir--

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: Then how would you explain the fact that out of one hundred twenty people we tested, you're the only one who came up positive for drugs?

turns.speaker: ATHENA
turns.text: I'm sorry, sir.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: When you were given the opportunity to enlist, a kind of contract was agreed upon. I think the Army has honored its part of that agreement.

turns.speaker: ATHENA
turns.text: Yes, sir--

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: Do you believe in what we're doing here, Private Johnson?

turns.speaker: ATHENA
turns.text: I-I can do the job, sir.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: You don't sound too enthusiastic.

turns.speaker: ATHENA
turns.text: I am, sir.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: What exactly do you think your job is, Private?

turns.speaker: ATHENA
turns.text: Follow orders. Do whatever they say.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: Who's "they"?

turns.speaker: ATHENA
turns.text: The--the officers.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: And that's the job? Nothing about serving your country?

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: ATHENA
turns.text: You really want to know, sir?

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: Please.

turns.speaker: ATHENA
turns.text: It's their country. This is one of the best deals they offer.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: How do you think I got to be a colonel?

turns.speaker: ATHENA
turns.text: Work hard, be good at your job. Sir. Do whatever they tell you.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: Do whatever they tell you--

turns.speaker: ATHENA
turns.text: I mean, follow orders, sir.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: With your attitude, Private, I'm surprised you want to stay in the service.

turns.speaker: ATHENA
turns.text: I do, sir.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: Because it's a job?

turns.speaker: ATHENA
turns.text: Outside it's--it's such a mess--it's--

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: Chaos.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: Why do you think they let us in on the "deal"?

turns.speaker: ATHENA
turns.text: They got people to fight. Arabs, yellow people, whatever. Might as well use us.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: Do you think you've been discriminated against on this post?

turns.speaker: ATHENA
turns.text: No, sir. Not at all.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: Any serious problems with your sergeant or your fellow soldiers?

turns.speaker: ATHENA
turns.text: No, sir. They all been real straight with me.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: Why don't you start with that?

turns.speaker: ATHENA
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: You're dismissed, Private.

turns.speaker: ATHENA
turns.text: Thank you, sir.

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: So you knew this young man before?

turns.speaker: ATHENA
turns.text: From back in Houston. We both come up on Fifth Street.

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: It's not our job to get involved in your personal life, but when it interferes with the training here--

turns.speaker: ATHENA
turns.text: I'm sorry, Sergeant Major. There wasn't anything I could do. Shadow gets crazy--

turns.speaker: ATHENA
turns.text: Sergeant Major? How is Richie doing? Private Graves?

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: He'll live.

turns.speaker: ATHENA
turns.text: Out of the Army?

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: He's going to lose a lung. This is not good news for Athena--

turns.speaker: ATHENA
turns.text: Will this go on my record?

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: If the incident happened the way you say it did, there hasn't been an infraction.

turns.speaker: ATHENA
turns.text: Thank you, Sergeant Major.

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: You're dismissed.

turns.speaker: ATHENA
turns.text: Thank you, Sergeant Major.

turns.speaker: PRISCILLA
turns.text: Did you know he was going to be there last night?

turns.speaker: ATHENA
turns.text: If I had I wouldn't have gone in.

turns.speaker: PRISCILLA
turns.text: And you and Private Graves--

turns.speaker: ATHENA
turns.text: We were just dancing--

turns.speaker: PRISCILLA
turns.text: We're not running a dating service here.

turns.speaker: ATHENA
turns.text: I know that, Sergeant. We were just dancing. There was a bunch of us there. Shadow just come down looking for trouble.

turns.speaker: PRISCILLA
turns.text: Private Johnson!

turns.speaker: ATHENA
turns.text: Sergeant?

turns.speaker: PRISCILLA
turns.text: Report to Dr. Innis at the clinic.

turns.speaker: ATHENA
turns.text: I'm feeling okay--

turns.speaker: PRISCILLA
turns.text: I'm very happy to hear that, Private. Now you go put some pee-pee in a cup for Dr. Innis and I'll be feeling okay, too.

turns.speaker: ATHENA
turns.text: You're testing me?

turns.speaker: PRISCILLA
turns.text: You and one hundred nineteen other fortunate individuals. Put it in gear.

turns.speaker: ATHENA
turns.text: Yes, Sergeant.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Sam the Man.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Hey, Ben. Thanks for coming down.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: How's business?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Business is booming. Got your drugs, got your illegals--had a shooting the other night at Big O's--Soldier got ventilated.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I hear they're closing that post down.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: September '97, that's all she wrote.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Gonna pull a lot of jobs out of this county.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Yeah, we'll have folks swimming over to Mexico to work in the sweatshops.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: That the word on our boy?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Yeah, this is Skinny.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Skinny?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: We find a body, it's either Skinny or Stinky, depending on how much meat there is on the bones.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Nice job.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Male, 40 to 50 years old, five-foot- eleven, chewed tobacco--then we get into the dental records--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Charley Wade.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: That badge--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: --it didn't come out of a cereal box.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You know the popular version of how he left town.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Everybody on the border knows that story.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You got a cause of death?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Skull was intact, no soft tissue left--not much to go on.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: So he could have gone out to the base, hopped the fence, dug down into the dirt on the old rifle range and had a heart attack.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: You uhm--you remember what old Buddy carried for a side arm?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Colt Peacemaker.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: He swore by it.  What?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Just wondering.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: So is Buddy on your short list?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: If it was some poor mojado, swam across at night, got lost in the scrub and starved out there, we wouldn't go any further. But this is a formerly prominent citizen.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You got to investigate. No question about it.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: What I will do is keep names out of it till we got some answers or hit a dead end. You know how the press is with a murder story--even if it's forty years old.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Yeah, it's a pretty cold trail.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: What's that for?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Jimmy got a kitchen full of wetbacks, most of 'em relatives. People breed like chickens.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: So?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I roust some muchacho on the street, doesn't have his papers, all he got to say is "Yo trabajo para Jimmy Herrera."

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: It's your deal. You sweated it out of him, you pick it up.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: There's gonna be some left over for you, Buddy. I take care of my boys.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: That's not the point.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: You feeling bad for Jimmy? Have him tell you the size of the mordida they took out of his hide when he run a place on the other side. Those old boys in Ciudad Leon--

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: I'm not picking it up.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: You do whatever I say you do or else you put it on the trail, son.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: You ever shoot anybody was looking you in the eye?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Who said anything about shootin' anybody?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Whole different story; isn't it?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: You're fired. You're outta the department.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: There's not a soul in this county isn't sick to death of your bullshit, Charley. You made yourself scarce, you could make a lot of people happy.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: You little pissant--

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Now or later, Charley. You won't have any trouble finding me.

turns.speaker: BUNNY
turns.text: The Longhorns gonna kick some serious butt this Saturday, you just watch. We got a kid at tailback from down your way--outta El Indio--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: That's in Maverick County.

turns.speaker: BUNNY
turns.text: Oh. Right. And you're in--?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Rio. BUNNY Right. This kid, Hosea Brown? Does tire 40 in 3.4, soft hands, lateral movement--the whole package. Only a sophomore--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You still going to all the home games?

turns.speaker: BUNNY
turns.text: Well, Daddy's got his box at the stadium, of course, and I'll fly to the Cowboy away games when they're in the Conference. Then there's the high school on Friday' nights. West Side got a boy 6'6", 310, moves like a cat. High school, we're talkin'. Guess how much he can bench-press?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Bunny, you--uhm--you on that same medication?

turns.speaker: BUNNY
turns.text: Do I seem jumpy?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: No, you look good. I was just wondering.

turns.speaker: BUNNY
turns.text: Last year was awful rough--Mama passing on and the whole business with O.J.--I mean it's not like it was Don Meredith or Roger Staubach or one of our own boys, but it really knocked me for a loop--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You look good--

turns.speaker: BUNNY
turns.text: --and that squeaker the Aggies dropped to Oklahoma-sonofabitch stepped in some lucky shit before he kicked that goal--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Yeah, well--

turns.speaker: BUNNY
turns.text: --they hadn't pulled me off that woman I would have jerked a knot in her.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You were in a fight--

turns.speaker: BUNNY
turns.text: Daddy calls it an "altercation." How you doing, Sam? You look skinny.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Same weight I always was.

turns.speaker: BUNNY
turns.text: You look awful good in that uniform, though.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Best part of the job.

turns.speaker: BUNNY
turns.text: Daddy hired a pinhead to take your job. He says so himself. Says "Even my son-in-law was better than this pinhead I got now".

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Bunny, is that stuff I left in the garage still there?

turns.speaker: BUNNY
turns.text: Least he never called me that. With me, it was always "high-strung." "My Bunny might have done something with her life, she wasn't so high-strung." Or "tightly wound," that was another one. You seeing anyone?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: No. You?

turns.speaker: BUNNY
turns.text: Yeah. Sort of. Daddy rounds 'em up. You aren't talking about money, their beady little eyes go dead.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You didn't--uhm--you didn't have one of your fires, did you? The stuff I left in the garage--some of it was my father's--

turns.speaker: BUNNY
turns.text: You watch the draft this year? 'Course you didn't, idiot question. They try to make it dramatic, like there's some big surprise who picks who in the first round? Only they been working it over with their experts and their computers for months. Doctor's reports, highlight reels, coaches' evaluations, psychological profiles--hell, I wouldn't be surprised if they collected stool samples on these boys, have 'em analyzed. All this stuff to pick a football player for your squad. Compared to that, what you know about the person you get married to don't amount to diddly, does it?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Suppose not.

turns.speaker: BUNNY
turns.text: You kind of bought yourself a pig in a poke, didn't you, Sam? All that time we were first seeing each other you didn't know I was tightly wound--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: It wasn't just you, Bunny.

turns.speaker: BUNNY
turns.text: No, it wasn't, was it? You didn't exactly throw yourself into it heart and soul, did you?

turns.speaker: BUNNY
turns.text: 350 pounds.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: BUNNY
turns.text: This boy from West Side, plays tackle both ways. Bench-presses 350 pounds. You imagine having that much weight on top of you? Pushing down? Be hard to breathe. Hard to swallow.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I think they have another fella there to keep it off your chest. A spotter.

turns.speaker: BUNNY
turns.text: "I only got my little girl now," he says, "she's my lifeline." Then he tells me I can't be in the box anymore if I can't control myself. Sonofabitch don't even watch the damn game, just sits there drinking with his bidness friends, look up at the TV now and then. I do better to sit in the cheap seats with some real football people.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You look good, Bunny. It's nice to see you.

turns.speaker: BUNNY
turns.text: Thanks. I like it when you say that, Sam.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: You'll get official notification when I make my decision. He is out the door--Otis pulls himself a beer as Carolyn steps back out--

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: So that's him--

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: Hey, it's the General.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: Colonel. Is uhm--is Otis in?

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: Come on in--

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: If it's too late--

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: Come on in.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: You've been in this house for a while?

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: I been here with him eight years now. He built it when he was with Leora.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: I never met her.

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: There was a bunch of 'em You never met. Me neither.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: Where'd he get all this?

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: Your mother got a brother--Alphonse--

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: Uncle Al--

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: Otis stood on good terms with the man. Whenever you do something makes the news, he sends it on. When they made you General, Otis just about drove away all our customers going on about it.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: I'm a colonel.

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: Yeah, I know--Man made me memorize the whole damn Army chain of command before he'd marry me. So this is a big deal, commander and  all?

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: It's a small post and they're phasing it out in two years, but I moved up in rank and--well, a command is a command.

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: Otis went on like you were that guy who won the Gulf War. Colin whatsit.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: My mother said he never asked about--

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: He never asked her.

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: You weren't in here tonight, were you?

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: No sir.

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: Go out through the back.

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: Spanish in Florida called him Juan Caballo. John Horse.

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: He a Black man or an Indian?

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: Both.

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: He was part of the Seminole Nation, got pushed down into the Everglades in pioneer days. African people who run off from the slaveholders hooked up with them, married up, had children. When the Spanish give up Florida, the U.S.Army come down to move all them Indian peoples off to Oklahoma--

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: The Trail of Tears.

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: They teaching that now?  Good. Only a couple of 'em held out--this man, John Horse, and his friend Wild Cat, and a fella name of Osceola. Army put all of them in prison and Osceola died, but them other two escaped and put together a fighting band and held out another ten, fifteen years. Beat Zach Taylor and a thousand troops at Lake Okeechobee.

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: So they stayed in Florida?

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: They got tired of fighting, went to the Indian Territories for a while. But the slave-raiders were on 'em even there, and one night they packed up and nearly the whole band rode down to Mexico. Crossed at Eagle Pass.

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: Men worked for Santa Anna down there, waited out the Civil War. The land wasn't much to feed people on, so in 1870 they come north and put up at Fort Duncan and the men joined up what was called the Seminole Negro Indian Scouts. Best trackers either side of the border. Bandits, rustlers, Texas rednecks, Kiowa, Comanche--

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: They fought against the Indians?

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: Same as they done in Mexico.

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: But they were Indians themselves.

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: They were in the Army. Like your father.

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: You know who I am?

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: I got a pretty good guess.

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: That guy who got shot--

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: You didn't go telling your father you were here?

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: Are you kidding? And face a court- martial?

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: He's a pretty tough old man, huh?

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: No sports if I don't keep a B average, no TV on school nights, no PDA's--

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: PDA?

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: Public Display of Affection. Every time he moves up a rank, it's like he's got to tighten the screws a little more--

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: Well--

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: I mean, just 'cause he didn't--you know--

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: Didn't have a father?

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: He's still pissed off about it.

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: When you're his age you'll still be pissed off about him.

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: So how come you got into all this?

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: These are our people. There were Paynes in Florida, Oklahoma, Piedras Negras--couple of 'em won the whatsit-- Congressional Medal Of Honor--

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: So I'm part-Indian?

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: By blood you are. But blood only means what you let it.

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: My father says the day you're  born you start from scratch, no breaks and no excuses, and you got to pull yourself up on your own.

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: Well, he's living proof of that, son. Living proof.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: Otis Payne was never embarrassed about a thing in his life.

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: Dad--

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: Dad--?

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: "Hey, Delmore, where's your Daddy?"

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: Big O was always there with a  smile or a loan or a free drink.

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: Dad, can I talk to you about track?

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: Dad, I talked to the track coach--

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: I thought we already had this out? Next year, if your grades are high enough--

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: I have a B average.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: How many B-average students do you think they take at West Point?

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: Homework?

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: I finished that. I'm just messing around.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: Tanks, huh?

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: You got to be in the Army, you might as well have something slick to drive.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: So you're going into the Army?

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: Not that I don't think you'd be good at it, but--you know--I wouldn't be disappointed if you decided to do something else with your life.

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: You wouldn't?

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: How's your room shaping up?

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: Fine. I'm pretty much moved in.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: Are we going to ever see your father?

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: My father.

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: Yeah. He lives here, right?

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: He does.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: Maybe we'll clean that thing out back up, have a barbecue next weekend. We could invite him and his wife over.

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: Cool.

turns.speaker: CHUCHO
turns.text: Recycling, right? We invented that. The government doesn't have to tell people to do it.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You own this place?

turns.speaker: CHUCHO
turns.text: This place, the one across the street, four other ones around Ciudad Leon-- soy el Rey de las Llantas. King of the Tires. Lots of your people rollin' back over that bridge on my rubber.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You lived in the States for a while?

turns.speaker: CHUCHO
turns.text: Fifteen years in El Paso.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Made some money, came back here--

turns.speaker: CHUCHO
turns.text: Something like that.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You ever know a fella named Eladio Cruz?

turns.speaker: CHUCHO
turns.text: Bird flying south-you think he sees that line? Rattlesnake, javelina-- whatever you got--halfway across that line they don't start thinking different. So why should a man?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Your government always been pretty happy to have that line. The question's just been where to draw it

turns.speaker: CHUCHO
turns.text: My government can go fuck itself, and so can yours. I'm talking about people here--men. Mi amigo Eladio Cruz is giving some friends of his a lift in his camion one day--

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: This place is a gold mine.

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: Lead mine.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: It's a lead mine.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: I don't know why I'm talking to you, you've got that thing on your head.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: You finding lots of cactus and shit?

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: It's not just cactus.  There's the nopals, the yuccas--

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Looks like a lot of cactus to me.

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: Man knows a hundred-fifty varieties of beer, he can't tell a poinsettia from a prickly pear.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Cliff--

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: You live in a place, you should know something about it. Explore--

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Cliff--

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: The Sheriff says we shouldn't touch anything,

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: He can't hear with that rig on-- Mikey!

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: Since I've been stationed here? A fistfight now and then--

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: We had a kid pass out in the men's room. The town isn't much.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Guy cracks walnuts with his asshole.

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: You get the feeling he doesn't want to be here?

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Never thought I'd see the day a buddy of mine was dating a woman with three up and three down on her shoulder.

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: I think it's beyond what you'd call dating.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: You going to get married?

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: Maybe.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: You met her family? They gonna be cool about you being a white guy?

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: Priscilla says they think any woman over 30 who isn't married must be a lesbian. She figures they'll be so relieved I'm a man--

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Always heartwarming to see a prejudice defeated by a deeper prejudice.  But marriage, man--I did two tours in Southeast Asia and I was married for five years--I couldn't tell you which experience was worse.

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: Hey, Mikey--

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: I knew she was Japanese going into it, but she didn't tell me the ninja assassin part--

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: Mikey--

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Her parents acted like I was gonna blow my nose on their curtains--

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: Mikey--

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: If I stayed out past ten with the guys she'd go into her Madame Butterfly routine--

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: Mikey look at this--

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: What--it's a bullet. I'm lousy with bullets here.

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: It's a .45.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: This is the stuff we picked up the other day, right? The rest of this is all .30 caliber--

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: They were using M-1's, yeah--

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: What's it doing on a rifle range?

turns.speaker: PRISCILLA
turns.text: He'll be transferred to a military hospital as soon as he's stabilized--

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: He'll probably be getting a medical discharge--

turns.speaker: PRISCILLA
turns.text: You spoil 'em, Cliff.

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: Hey--she's in a tough situation. I cut her some slack--

turns.speaker: PRISCILLA
turns.text: But I'm the one in charge of her sorry ass.

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: She's pulled herself out of a pretty rough neighborhood.

turns.speaker: PRISCILLA
turns.text: So where does that put us?

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: Well--I don't see what's changed. No - PDA's, no necking on the obstacle course.

turns.speaker: PRISCILLA
turns.text: Seriously.

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: Seriously, I think we should get married.

turns.speaker: PRISCILLA
turns.text: We been through this before--

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: We should just do it.

turns.speaker: PRISCILLA
turns.text: And if I get a shot at a promotion somewhere--

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: You could take it--

turns.speaker: PRISCILLA
turns.text: It's up or out these days, Cliff. Say I get transferred to a different post--

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: I'd quit the Army for you, if it came to that.

turns.speaker: PRISCILLA
turns.text: Man's gonna retire in two years and he offer to quit. Big goddamn deal.

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: They stopped training infantry there in the late '50s. It was just a playground for the jackrabbits till they gave it to the county last year.

turns.speaker: PRISCILLA
turns.text: You know who it was they dug up?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I was driving back from Apache Wells when they got me on the radio.

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: This was a rifle range way back when. But we figured it isn't Army land anymore, it's your jurisdiction.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I've got the forensics fella coming down from the Rangers. No way to know how old the body is without some lab work.

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: That ring--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Masons been around a long while.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Treasure hunter?

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: Old bullets.  He uhm-- makes art with them.

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: Sheriff--hi--this is Sergeant--this is Priscilla Worth.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Pleased to meet you.

turns.speaker: CLIFF
turns.text: Sheriff Deeds was in on our archeological find yesterday.

turns.speaker: CODY
turns.text: Now I'm just as liberal as the next guy--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: If the next guy's a redneck.

turns.speaker: CODY
turns.text: --but I gotta say I think there's something to this cold climate business. I mean, you go to the beach- what do you do? Drink a few beers, wait for a fish to flop up on the sand. Can't build no civilization that way. You got a hard winter coming, though, you got to plan ahead, and that gives your cerebral cortex a workout.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Good deal you were born down here, then.

turns.speaker: CODY
turns.text: You joke about it, Sam, but we are in a state of crisis. The lines of demarcation has gotten fuzzy--to run a sucessfull civilization you got to have lines of demarcation between right and wrong, between this one and that one--your Daddy understood that. He was like the whatchacallit-- the referee for this damn menudo we got down here. He understood how most people don't want their sugar and salt in the same jar.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You mixed drinks bad as you mix metaphors, you be out of a job.

turns.speaker: CODY
turns.text: Take that pair over in the corner--

turns.speaker: CODY
turns.text: --warning. Not 'cause he had it in for the colored

turns.speaker: CODY
turns.text: --but just as a kind of safety tip.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Yeah. I bet he would.

turns.speaker: CODY
turns.text: Old Sam stood for somethin', you know? The day that man died they broke the goddamn mold.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: There's not that much down here, Colonel. Big O's is the only place in the county that our African American soldiers are uhm--that they feel comfortable in.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: Have we had trouble there before?

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: You know how it is, Colonel--first time away from home, dealing with new people--I remember my first hitch--

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: Substance abuse?

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Well, yeah, but I went through the Program. I haven't had a drink since--

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: I meant on the post. In general. How are you dealing with it?

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: I sprint the last quarter mile. You gentlemen don't have to keep up if you don't care to.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Appreciate it, sir.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: Black Seminoles?

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: Hobby of mine. Got some artifacts, couple pieces one of your men out at the base made. Free admission.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: That where he was shot?

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: That's where he fell.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: You get much of that in here?

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: It's a bar. People come together, drink, fall in love, fall out of love, air their grudges out--

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: Deal drugs in the bathroom--

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: If I thought it would help I'd put up a sign telling them not to. Right under the one about the employees washing their hands.

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: This here's Carolyn. Honey, this is my son, Delmore.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: Nice to meet you, Ma'am.

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: So.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: So tell me why I shouldn't make this place off-limits.

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: This is an official visit, then--

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: I assume a lot of your business is from our people.

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: Your boys out there cooped up together, need somewhere they can let the steam out. If they're Black, there's not but one place in this town they feel welcome. Been that way since before you were born.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: We have an enlisted man's club at the post.

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: Well, you're the Man out there now, aren't you? It's your call.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: I been hearing rumors about this new commander coming for a couple weeks now. Boys say they heard he's a real hard case. Spit-and-polish man. Full- bird colonel name of Payne, they say-- Bet you never figured you end up back here.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: The Army hands you a command, you go wherever it is.

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: I hear things, too.  People call you the Mayor of Darktown.

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: Over the years, this is the one place that's always been there. I loan a little money out, settle some arguments. Got a cot in the back- people get afraid to go home they can spend the night. There's not enough of us to run anything in this town- the white people are mostly out on the lake now and the Mexicans hire each other. There's the Holiness Church and there's Big O's place.

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: And people make their choice--

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: A lot of 'em choose both. There's not like a borderline between the good people and the bad people--you're not either on one side or the other--

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: I gonna meet that family of yours?

turns.speaker: DEL
turns.text: Why would you want to do that?

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: Because I'm your father.
